_exec_summary.SummaryText:
PeroxyChem's Tonawanda, NY manufacturing facility is committed to conducting business in a manner that protects the safety and health of its employees, contractors, customers, and the environment.   PeroxyChem is a subsidiary of the Evonik Corporation.  It is committed to conducting business in a manner that is comparable with the balanced environmental needs of the community in which it operates. This commitment requires compliance with all applicable laws and regulations, facilities which are designed and operated to high standards, and systematic identification and management of safety, health, and environmental risks. In keeping with this commitment, PeroxyChem's Tonawanda Plant has established a comprehensive Safety Management System that strives to identify and eliminate all potential exposures that include, but are not limited to, personal injury/illness, property damage, fires, process incidents, and breaches of security. The Safety Management System embodies and employs the spirit and intent of the concepts found in the ACC Responsible Care Initiative, the OSHA PSM Standard, all other applicable regulatory standards, and PeroxyChem' s Corporate Safety and Industrial Hygiene Policies and strategies.



The Plant's Safety Policy:



PeroxyChem is committed to operating a safe facility. All employees are responsible for creating a safe and healthy workplace for themselves, their fellow employees, visitors, the community, and our customers. Our daily activities will be guided by the following principles:



?    All injuries are preventable, and an injury-free workplace is achievable.

?    Every employee is responsible and will be held accountable for working safely, knowing and following plant rules and procedures, and maintaining a safe work environment.

?    Employees need to be aware of potential hazards, should feel free to discuss their safety and health concerns, and shall participate in improving our plant work conditions and safe work behaviors.

?    We will co

mmunicate openly with mutual trust to meet our safety and health goals.

?    The STRIDE behavior-based safety process is key to continuous attitudes and values.

?    Safety performance is a direct reflection on a person's safety attitude and values.

?    The company will provide and maintain safe equipment, processes and procedures, provide safety training, and will comply with safety regulations, OSHA Process Safety Management, EPA Risk Management Program.

Every employee is responsible and will be held accountable for working safely, knowing and following plant rules and procedures, and maintaining a safe work environment. The company will provide and maintain safe equipment, processes, procedures, safety training, and will comply with safety regulations.



Management at PeroxyChem's Tonawanda Plant has authorized specific risk management programs and activities in compliance with EPA's Risk Management Program ruling (40 CFR Part 68) that assesses the hazards of the processes which handle or store more than the threshold quantity of substances regulated by the EPA, prevent accidental releases of these hazardous substances, and effectively respond to emergencies if a release occurs.



Description - Peroxychem's Tonawanda Plant produces active oxidant products for shipment to external users. The covered process is the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia (CAS 07664-41-7). The plant also produces peracetic acid (CAS 79-21-0) for shipment to external users, but it is not a covered process since the vapor pressure is less than 10 mm Hg.



Worst case Scenario - RMP regulations require a consequence analysis for worst case scenario in each regulated process, estimated to present the greatest distance in any direction to a toxic endpoint.



The worst-case scenario selected for this process was the complete loss of the contents of one full ammonia railcar of 161,000 pounds within ten (10) minutes. The distance to toxic endpoint (0.14 mg/l) is 6.9 miles. The estimated re

sidential population within the area is ~375,000. Modeling was performed using RMP*Comp assuming rural conditions and a wind speed of 1.5 m/sec. Rural conditions were deliberately chosen to create a more conservative approach as was the F class stability. Public impact includes, schools, residences, hospitals, recreation areas, and major commercial offices or industrial areas. Environmental impacts include state parks and wildlife sanctuaries, preserves or refuges.



Alternate Release Scenarios - RMP regulations require that at least one alternate release scenario be identified and analyzed for each regulated toxic chemical present. A scenario that is more realistic than the worst-case scenario was selected as the alternate release case.



The alternate release scenario simulates an ammonia railcar transfer line rupture. The event is assumed to release 6,840 pounds of ammonia during a twenty (20) minute period at a rate of 342 pounds per minute. The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint (0.14 mg/l) is 0.3 miles. This scenario was modeled using the RMP*Comp and assumed a complete rupture of the liquid transfer hose during railcar unloading. The loss was assumed to be for a twenty (20) minutes duration with a manual response to close the railcar unloading valve and did not account for the excess flow valve in place on the railcar in order to keep the model conservative. The estimated residential population within the area is ~4300. Public impact includes parks and recreational areas, and major commercial offices and industrial buildings. The institutions, parks, and recreational areas within the 0.3 mile radius from the release source were located using WNY street maps from Map Works, Inc. No environmental contacts were impacted. This scenario did not take into account any of the automatic devices installed in the unloading system and is therefore considered conservative. The actual response time should be less than a minute upon detection of a release in this sc

enario.



Five Year Accident History - No reportable releases of ammonia have occurred in the past 5 years.

Prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances at the Tonawanda Plant involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures, and management practices. These prevention programs comply with all applicable requirements of OSHA's PSM regulations, as stipulated in 26 CFR 1910.119, and all applicable EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) requirements, as stipulated by 40 CFR Part 68. The nature of the processes and the type and quantities of hazardous substances present require that these processes be considered as "Program 3" processes for EPA RMP regulations. The following elements are included in the Safety Management system at Tonawanda: 0. Management Responsibility; 1. Process Safety Information (General information - SDS's, SOP's, Safety Procedures, Process Controls, Equipment Manuals, Design Files, Product Safety, Process Technology, and Equipment Safety); 2. Process Hazards Reviews; 3. Operating Procedures; 4. Training; 5. Mechanical Integrity; 6. Management of Change; 7. Pre-Start-Up Safety Reviews; 8. Compliance Audits; 9. Incident Investigations; 10. Employee Participation; 11. Hot Work Permits; 12. Contractor Safety; 13. Site Security activities including a Site Vulnerability Analysis.



Emergency Response Program - The PeroxyChem Tonawanda Plant Emergency Response Program involves the preparation of an Emergency Response Plan tailored to each process and the emergency response services that are available in the nearby community. The Emergency Response Plan complies with EPA Emergency Response Program requirements stipulated in 40 CFR Part 68.
